review.title: Virtual Embodiment: A Scalable Long-Term Strategy for Artificial Intelligence Research
review.abstract: Meaning has been called the "holy grail" of a variety of scientific disciplines, ranging from linguistics to philosophy, psychology and the neurosciences. The field of Artifical Intelligence (AI) is very much a part of that list: the development of sophisticated natural language semantics is a sine qua non for achieving a level of intelligence comparable to humans. Embodiment theories in cognitive science hold that human semantic representation depends on sensori-motor experience; the abundant evidence that human meaning representation is grounded in the perception of physical reality leads to the conclusion that meaning must depend on a fusion of multiple (perceptual) modalities. Despite this, AI research in general, and its subdisciplines such as computational linguistics and computer vision in particular, have focused primarily on tasks that involve a single modality. Here, we propose virtual embodiment as an alternative, long-term strategy for AI research that is multi-modal in nature and that allows for the kind of scalability required to develop the field coherently and incrementally, in an ethically responsible fashion.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 161 0.07 432v 1 [cs.A I] 2 4O ct2 016Virtual Embodiment: A Scalable Long-Term Strategy for Artificial Intelligence Research Douwe Kiela Facebook AI Research New York, NY 10017, USA dkiela @ fb.com Luana Bulat, Anita L. Vero, Stephen Clark Computer Laboratory, University of Cambridge CB3 0FD, UK {ltf24, alv34, sc609} @ cam.ac.uk

sections.heading: 2 Grounding Semantics in Virtual Perception
sections.text: A fundamental problem of semantics is that of grounding [5], which refers to the definition of the meaning of a symbol by other symbols. In the context of Searle's famous arguments for space [6], it can be said that it is possible to learn from nothing but a (very complex) Chinese dictionary. "In other words, semantic representations popular in natural language processing, the exhibits of the distribution hypothesis are used.

sections.heading: 3 Desiderata
sections.text: It is worth outlining the characteristics that video games could have if they are to be suitable platforms for the development of AI through virtual embodiment. To this end, we propose a hierarchy1 of the types of embodied manifestations that an agent could have in a world. • Type 1: The same kind of hierarchy applies to both physical and virtual worlds: • Type 0: Agents perform basic first-order interactions with the world, with complete or limited access to the objective state of the world. • Type 1: Communication can be used for the exchange of knowledge about the state of the world. • Type 2: As above, but with higher-level interactions, i.e., with an element of planning, strategy and non-monotonous thinking. Communication is indispensable for the exchange of knowledge about the world. • Type 3: The world should be strictly non-deterministic and multimodal.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: We propose virtual embodiment through video games as a scalable long-term strategy for the research of artificial intelligence. Embodiment is indispensable for the development of semantics of natural language on a human level, which we consider to be a core aspect of artificial intelligence. Virtual embodiment enables the complexity of virtual worlds to be increased in line with the complexity of artificial agents, making them a suitable test ground for artificial intelligence, and in an ethically responsible manner. 1 Inspired by the Kardashev scale for the complexity of civilizations [37].

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This research was made possible by the European Research Council's GROUNDFORCE PoC fellowship.

referenceMentions.context: Meaning has been called the “holy grail” of a variety of scientific disciplines, ranging from linguistics to philosophy, psychology and the neurosciences [1].

Embodiment theories in cognitive science hold that human semantic representation depends on sensori-motor experience [2]; the abundant evidence that human meaning representation is grounded in the perception of physical reality leads to the conclusion that meaning must depend on a fusion of multiple (perceptual) modalities [3].

Ethical testability: Importantly, since artificial agents are exposed to a constrained environment, virtual worlds provide the ultimate testing ground for carefully fleshing out important ethical considerations in relation to artificial intelligence [4], without any potentially damaging immediate consequences in the physical world.
A fundamental problem of semantics is the grounding problem [5], which concerns the circularity in defining the meaning of a symbol through other symbols.

In the context of Searle’s famous Chinese Room argument [6], it can be phrased as: is it possible to learn Chinese from nothing but a (very sophisticated) Chinese dictionary? Modern representation learning approaches, including the word embeddings that have become popular in natural language processing, are exponents of the distributional hypothesis [7], which stipulates that you “shall know the meaning of a word through the company that it keeps” [8].

Second, these approaches lack any interaction, which plays an important role in language acquisition: children learn basic language understanding by interacting with the environment, and build more intricate “reflective reasoning” on top of that foundation [19].
There has been work in linguistic grounding that allows for temporal aspects, for instance in videos [20, 21, 22], and both time and interaction, notably in the field of robotics [23, 24, 25].

We specifically advocate multiagent video games “with a purpose” [36], rather than alternative virtual worlds that lack gamification, since they provide interesting platforms for humans to engage with for extended periods of time, without the explicit purpose of teaching machines to achieve a certain task.
The real world is enormously complex, and performing common sense reasoning in such a complicated environment has long been one of AI’s classic problems in the shape of the frame problem [38].
Inspired by the Kardashev scale for the sophistication of civilizations [37].
